centralQuestion: Should Colorado ban fracking and new oil drilling in light of climate change?

reasons.description: Banning new drilling aligns with net-zero pathways that state there should be no new oil and gas field approvals beyond those already committed.

Persistent ozone nonattainment on Colorado’s Front Range—driven in part by oil and gas emissions—poses ongoing public health risks that stricter measures (including halting new drilling) are intended to reduce.

sources.title: Environmental Protection Agency: 'Colorado Ozone Planning (2025 update)'

reasons.description: Compliance failures and secrecy around fracking chemicals in Colorado have raised health and transparency concerns, cited by advocates for halting new drilling.

sources.title: The Guardian: 'US oil firms pumping secret chemicals into ground and not fully reporting it'

reasons.description: Economic transition research suggests Western Colorado communities can build resilience beyond oil and gas, supporting arguments to curb new drilling as part of a planned shift.

sources.title: Resources for the Future: 'Building Economic Resilience in Western Colorado’s Oil and Gas Communities'

reasons.description: Local climate accountability litigation in Colorado underscores community claims of harm from fossil fuel use, bolstering calls to restrict or end new drilling.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Exxon, Suncor units lose bid to escape Boulder, Colorado’s climate case'

objections.description: Colorado is a major oil producer; a ban risks significant impacts on jobs, state revenues, and related economic activity.

sources.title: Energy Information Administration: 'Colorado State Energy Profile Analysis'

objections.description: Cutting supply in one jurisdiction can shift production elsewhere; reducing demand (not domestic production) is argued as the more effective climate strategy.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'Reducing US oil demand, not production, is the way forward for the climate'

objections.description: Bans face legal and jurisdictional hurdles in Colorado (state preemption and litigation over local authority), complicating implementation.

sources.title: PBS NewsHour: 'Colorado fights over who decides where to frack'

objections.description: Analyses suggest blanket drilling bans can impose high welfare costs relative to alternative regulatory approaches.

sources.title: Resources for the Future: 'Understanding the Costs and Benefits of Deepwater Oil Drilling Regulation'

objections.description: Opponents argue leasing or fracking bans undermine energy security and raise prices; they advocate continued production alongside climate policy.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: 'Biden’s Incoherent Proposal to Ban Fossil Fuel Leasing on Federal Lands'

objections.description: Analysts note a ban on certain lands could simply shift activity to private lands, limiting climate benefits.

sources.title: Council on Foreign Relations: 'FAQ: A Shale New Deal'

research.title: ‘Ideas and perspectives: is shale gas a major driver of recent increase in global atmospheric methane?’ (Biogeosciences, 2019)
research.description: Argues that shale oil and gas development has likely contributed substantially to the recent rise in atmospheric methane, highlighting implications for climate policy and the role of fracking-related emissions.

research.title: ‘Maternal residential proximity to unconventional gas development and perinatal outcomes among a diverse urban population in Texas’ (PLOS ONE, 2017)
research.description: Finds suggestive associations between proximity to unconventional gas development and increased odds of preterm birth and fetal death, using a large Texas cohort.

research.title: ‘Publicly available data reveals association between asthma hospitalizations and unconventional natural gas development in Pennsylvania’ (PLOS ONE, 2022)
research.description: Uses statewide public data to show significant positive associations between well density and asthma hospitalization rates, with stronger associations for PM2.5.

research.title: ‘Birth Outcomes and Maternal Residential Proximity to Natural Gas Development in Rural Colorado’ (Environmental Health Perspectives, 2014)
research.description: Colorado-based retrospective cohort study reporting associations between density/proximity of natural gas wells and certain adverse birth outcomes.

research.title: ‘Air pollution, methane super-emitters, and oil and gas wells in the United States’ (Environmental Health, 2021)
research.description: Examines air pollution and methane super-emitter patterns around oil and gas infrastructure, discussing public health implications relevant to unconventional development.
